title: Palmerston North institution Cafe Express on the market
text:
Palmerston North institution Cafe Express on the market PAUL MITCHELL Last updated 14:13, February 14 2017 David Unwin/Fairfax NZ. 
Cafe Express owners Gerard and Claire Quigan are selling the iconic cafe after 14 years to move closer to family in Australia. 
The owners of Cafe Express are selling up after more than a decade behind the counter of the popular Palmerston North eatery. 
â€‹Cafe Express has been a fixture of the city's cafe scene for decades, but for the past 14 years husband and wife team Gerard and Claire Quigan have been the driving force behind it. 
The couple said the reason for the sale was because they were moving to Australia to be closer to family, including their two adult children. 
Palmerston North's Cafe Express will soon be under new management after owners Gerard and Claire Quigan put it on the market. 
Gerard Quigan, who also runs the kitchen, said part of their success had been recognising Cafe Express was a community that the owners should act as caretakers for. 
READ MORE: * Palmerston North man keeps coming back to Cafe Express for chips and croissant 
"It's like a village. The customers know each other and the staff. They come to catch up with everybody, not just for a meal or a coffee." 
He said it had been a privilege to be a part of that for so long, but it was time for them to move on. 
"It's definitely bittersweet," he said. "[The cafe] has been an incredibly big part of my life, the customers and staff are like family to us." 
In 2003, Gerard Quigan became friendly with a group of people who operated Cafe Express together. 
The group eventually invited he and Claire, who works front of house, on as part-owners. Ad Feedback 
At the time the cafe was a slowly fading local legend, he said. 
"They wanted someone to come on board as an owner and right the ship, and the rest was history." 
Cafe Express had been in a rough patch, but they rebuilt on a solid foundation of the loyal regulars and bought full-ownership in 2008, he said. 
The couple had been touched by the sentiment and well-wishes from regulars and staff since they announced their plans to leave. 
Gerard Quigan said he wanted to reassure customers that nothing would change straight away, as they planned to leave the cafe in the hands of senior managers until a new owner was found. 
"I'm fully confident they will continue the good work as we enjoy our new life." 
Hospitality New Zealand regional manager Chris Hince said Quigan would be missed, and whoever took over from the couple had "big shoes to fill". 
He said Quigan had been a staunch advocate for high quality, professionalism, the workers and the customers in the Manawatu hospitality industry. 
"Gerard is always willing to give back...He's been a steady, sensible voice on any issue that's come up. 
"It's never been for his own personal gain, it's always been for the industry as a whole." 
The cafe was named Cafe of the Year at the 2014 Manawatu Hospitality Awards. In the same year Gabrielle Eyres and Bridget Grimes were nominated for Waiter of the Year and Emerging Chef respectively.
